comment.body: Yes imap for zeromail would be cool, but I think it would be quite difficult to implement, as the two models are very different. And in addition, I don't like if the sender can delete messages from my inbox.

definitely firefox, and variations of it like icecat,  abrowser on trisquel, iceweasel on debian. After the issue with the binary blob last year, I keep usage of chromium to a minimum. The only thing still missing in firefox is FIDO U2FA.
I'm using LUKS. Never had a problem so far.
@Shellbound: From sid it's usually two weeks to testing. Lots of people run their machines with rolling testing. And lots of distros are based on debian testing.
@Durand: How does that behave if the epub has DRM?

@Durand: Sure I wasn't saying epub was bad because it allowed DRM. Just wondered how epub's with DRM behave. I only have epub's without DRM on my ebook reader. I don't buy DRM'd stuff on principle. So I guess an epub with DRM doesn't behave like a zip file that you can open freely anymore. Or is the encumberment on the individual embedded html files?
the user is required to commit to using the Turris router as the main internet gateway for his network for a specified period of time, and not to intervene in collection of data.
Do you know if it can be used for mesh networks?
I run into the exact same problem on a regular basis. I don't buy DRM'd stuff on principle. So I have the choice of ordering a dead tree edition, or read something else.

Even "The internet of money" by Andreas Antonopoulus is only available for Kindle. On the bright side, all books from Cory Doctorow are available as DRM free epub. But he didn't put up a BitCoin donation address yet.
@Dergatt: maybe a symlink? Or if there is nothing else on the USB stick, you could even mount it to ~/.ipfs
On another note, I wonder how much longer we have to wait for an ipfs debian package.
Cool, do you have a link to the kickstarter page?
Definitely! Price finding hasn't happened yet, so I wouldn't invest a lot. The technology is very interesting. The founders reward and how the company is set up is a bit controversial.
Really? Somebody should start something like  https://99bitcoins.com/bitcoinobituaries/  for zeronet then.
Wow, it must take some courage to take drugs in front of a camera and publish it.

@Nofish: Sure, but it can still have consequences nonetheless, especially if everybody can see it. Just imagine the questions on a job interview. Or if you look for new health insurance. Luckily we still have self determination. So, make use of it ;-)
Sounds amazing. Congratulations!
And once the hacker knows the master password.... People should really demand U2FA everywhere.
MDMA is on the verge of government approval as a treatment for PTSD : http://www.theplaidzebra.com/31082-2/
Wow, cool. I enjoyed reading the book. If only there was a way to legally watch the series, without entering an auto-renewing contract with Netflix.
Signal is not available for Ubuntu phone as far as I can tell.
It's the same with every religion. Except maybe the pastafari.
The question is, do the poor people pay for the service themselves or is it the state?
@ks: U2FA to be precise
Where would the world be without corruption?

Yes, electrum is my favorite as well. There are sites on how to earn some BTC by watching ad videos, and there might still be faucets.
You can sell something on OpenBazaar.
Or you can offer services for BTC.
@Flyman: I have a link to my blog on my ZeroMe profile page.
@Flyman: Just sent you a small amount that should be enough to pay for a beer in your favorite Bitcoin accepting bar.

@Flyman: Yes, exactly that's the exchange rate. I still think in USD/BTC. But you can configure the unit in both bitcoinity and electrum. I thought Russia is becoming more and more Bitcoin friendly. There are only very few countries where it is illegal. It is not as anonymous as some might think. So think twice before using your coins for stuff that is illegal in your jurisdiction. Namely I would never use BTC for online gambling or buying illegal stuff such as drugs or unregistered weapons.

@Flyman: I'm in Switzerland. https://coinmap.org/#/world/48.76343114/30.98144531/6  lists a couple of places in Ukraine. You can use Bitcoin anonymously, but then you have to be very careful and know how things work. Usually it is best to assume it can be traced with enough work.

It's comparable to burning bank notes. But bank notes are printed all the times. Since the Bitcoin supply is fixed, loosing your keys reduces the supply. So in theory you make the remaining coins more valuable. OFC since nobody knows about the stuck BTC, it is unlikely to have a real impact.
@Nextbit: Not infinitely, but to eight decimals. At the current price that is three more than traditional currencies. That means one satoshi equals 0.001 pennies.

@Flyman: 1. kind of, yes. Think of it as a giant asyclic directed graph. By labeling some vertices, and connecting the dots, and some guesswork, you can learn a lot.    2. Yes it is a map of BTC accepting venues. That is what I want to use BTC for. I want to use it to pay for stuff. If I can only use it to trade, then it hasn't reached it's goal. But if that is what you are interested, then check out https://localbitcoins.com/  and https://bitsquare.io/   3. Sounds possible, but overly complicated. Why do you need to create a zeronet page for that?

The amount of BTC is not relevant. With the tx fee you pay the miners for the space the information of your transaction uses in the blockchain. Contributing factors are multiple inputs, multiple outputs, multisig (pay to script hash) or other scripting. In electrum you can select a tx and right click details.
That reminds me, aren't there any good offline translators?
Didn't they have two bump's? We used to fold them to make turtles...

I have a physical card from xapo. It works very well, and the conversion from BTC to FIAT happens only when I spend.  I also use a virtual card from wirex (former e-coin) occasionally. Worked well so far, but there I have to top up in FIAT, so the conversion from BTC happens earlier. Just yesterday I used the virex card to pay the dyndns bill. They used an exchange rate of 2150 while the average was 2850.
Good for EU citizens. Swiss people still pay as before.
I wanted to get into ham radio for years. But I keep postponing...
ssh is usually easiest.
Is it with real actors or animated? The picture looks more like a cartoon.
Looks cool. If it's only for a prank it is costly. But if you have real use then it might be fine. At this price point, I prefer to try before buy.
If you do order, please report back how you like them.
It's slightly more expensive, but the Dell XPS 13 developer edition is the best notebook I have seen so far. Also the puri.sm devices make a very good impression.
Reminds me of a guy how jumped from a bridge. The person he fell upon had more serious injuries than he himself.
@Binchan @nofish: Any chance of this getting integrated in the ZeroNet distribution? So that users don't have to fiddle around and run the risk of incompatibilities after upgrades.
Where do you get the stuff you read? I avoid DRM like the plague. But drm-free books are hard to get. Thus I often end up buying the dead tree editions.
Depends on what hubs you seed, and who you follow.

@Binchan: I don't mind paying the authors, and even in a smaller part the distributors. But I want to be able to have access to my books whenever I want, wherever I want, without violating some abusive agreement. Of the few authors I asked so far where I could get a DRM free version, none had a positive answer. So I bought the paperbacks. I like the books from Cory Doctorow, and that he shares them with a permissive license. But when I wanted to donate some BTC to him, I couldn't find an address where to send...  Something like the unfortunately no longer available libertymusicstore, but for eBooks would be great.

@Binchan: My donations have been almost exclusively in Bitcoin for a couple of years. If somebody doesn't want my money, then he doesn't get anything. Donating is voluntary, and so is receiving them. Receiving and converting BTC is really not difficult. It's not like if somebody donated a cow, and now you have to care for it.

@Binchan: Segwit in itself does not add a lot for the user, at least on the surface, but Lightning does. Current implementations of Lightning rely on Segwit, although other malleability fixes would theoretically also work. I'm very optimistic for Lightning.  Energy is an issue, but one that is not so easy to solve. If proof by something else worked, it would be like perpetual motion: highly desirable, but very hard to achieve. Asic resistance doesn't solve the energy issue, it is only a bit better for decentralization. But even for Monero there are some ASICS in the planning. If somebody considers Bitcoin unethical, he either works for a bank, or feels he was too late to the game. I can understand FOMO only to a certain degree. It should be more about the transaction properties and censureship resistance than about the price. Thinking about ethics, I collected some stories here: [Why I prefer Bitcoin](/13UYenBm13vidxEA9DxKMSA3CJacWdkpke)

Don't be discouraged if nobody comments. Sometimes people have something to say about a topic, and sometimes they don't.    
Sometimes I wonder where people go when they leave zeronet. The platforms that I discovered after it, didn't really convince me. I like p2p better than federated. It is so cool if you can just join the network, and don't have to run a server, or go to a trusted server to host your profile.

@Binchan: I'm hosting our [official team blog](/wavebtc.bit) for the [WAVE trophy](http://www.wavetrophy.com/route-ch2018) on ZeroNet. I'm curious how many people actually check out what ZeroNet is all about and end up running a node. Most will for sure just use the proxy. I just hope the proxy stays operational at least until the WAVE is over.
@Binchan: Thanks :-)
How does it compare to ZeroMe? I hear a lot of people advertising Mastodon. But I feel like the federated server system is a step backwards.

@Musickillerwork: Sure, but I suspect a Mastodon server is a lot more difficult to set up and run than Zeronet. I wanted to get into Diaspora for a long time, but I was not willing to jum trough all the hoops to run a node. And I suspect it's a similar story with Mastodon.
And it still works?
Welcome back to ZeroNet
@Floppycasio: Depends if you want humans or giant vertebrates to rule the planet.

https://keybase.io/ulrichard But I use it only rarely. I prefer real signatures on the gpg key from in person verification.

Bitcoin runs mostly on renewables. How about deep learning?
Are you in Leipzig attending live? I always wanted to go. But in the past I didn't have the money, and now I don't have the time.

Wow, congratulations. How long and how often do you train. I have a co worker who runs marathons. It is one of those things that I always think I might go for some day. But then I have lots of things that are more important to me in the short term.
Even if gasoline was free, I would still prefer to drive electric.
@draugrdeathlord@zeroid.bit: In many instances renewable energy is already now cheaper than fossil. That trend is only going to accelerate. The currently cheap oil is only an annomality.
@draugrdeathlord@zeroid.bit: I never bought crude oil. But operating the gasoline powered cars in the past costs me more than six times as much as my current electric car.
